The long exposure to UV light does not BREAK DOWN the fluorescence, it depletes the chemicals, which take time to be replenished. It is like looking at a bright red sheet of paper then quickly looking at a yellow sheet of paper. The yellow sheet of paper will appear to be green. That is because your eyes have three color receptors (cones), red, green, and blue. Yellow is a combination of red and green, so when you deplete the chemicals in the red receptor and quickly look at the yellow, only the green receptor will be activated. If you wait a short time the colors will return to normal as your eye replenishes the chemical in the red receptor.

Depleting a chemical is not breaking down a chemical.

From a genetic engineer point of view I’d say:

Scorpion are fluorescent because they live in arid environment where there is not a lot of vegetation to absorb UV radiation and where the soil reflect UV back to any living creature.

Because UV causes a multitude of DNA mutations, as a result, the ability to protect DNA from UV for any living creature in that environment has represented a selection pressure. Scorpion absorb UV and developed other sensors to detect light (and probably heat) in that purpose.

Also most proteins absorb UV around 280nm (260nm for DNA) and becomes fluorescent, this is not an unnatural process. But it would be interesting to know what protein or chemical scorpions synthesise to get a protection and how they renew it.

I'm going to go out on a limb here and suggest that a couple of these hypotheses seem flawed. The scorpions, placed in a Petri dish and "blinded" with black paint over their eyes displaying the same reaction to UV light as the un-blinded, does not completely prove that their tail functions as an occular receptor.  Obviously, there must exist additional research to support that claim. Likewise...I'm going to venture out a little further onto a leaf blowing in the wind, and say that the flourescence of scorpions most likely is a genetic trait handed down through evolution, from underwater ancestors of the deep. The genetic advantage of "florescence" seems to be of greater use, as an underwater light , where there exists no light from the surface.

Sorry to the gentleman in this setting but...

Taking the traditional scientific approach of reductionism and following rigorous science; the study of a specific adaptation or trait by narrowly studying one effect at a time, is ... usually extremely ineffective.

Scorpions are the result of a chaotic environment with dynamically adapting genes. Performing reductionist derived reasoning on this makes almost every study discussed in this video entirely moot.

Firstly, whilst he covers it SO BRIEFLY he genuinely doesn't give it enough discourse... The apt metaphor to describe the trait would be a SPANDREL. A phenotypic trait that is an unintended (and often unavoidable) evolutionary consequence of other adaptations.

But I digress...

STUDY THE ANIMAL IN ITS ENVIRONMENT. It doesn't matter WHAT animal it is. This astounds me that poor biology is still conducted AND accepted.

Collecting the scorpion, placing it in a lab environment... what does it tell you? It tells you how a scorpion you interfered with behaves in an environment that is TOTALLY DETATCHED FROM THE ONE IT ADAPTED FOR.

Like yeesh. It's common sense, but it took scientists CENTURIES to realise that.

Observational studies are the most effective. So derive an index for the scorpions of how flourescent they are and observe them in their environment.

Duh.

HIGHLY recommended Dr Robert M Sapolsky for a genuine eye-opening experience about scientific rigor over the last century regarding biology, evolution and behaviour.

Why does everyone always get confused about this? UV fluorescence is in the VISIBLE light range. It consists of UV light being turned into VISIBLE light. Being able to see in the UV spectrum therefore doesn't help an organism see UV fluorescence any better than an organism that is able to only see in the visible light spectrum. At night, a fluorescent organism looks pretty much the same to every other organism with color vision as it does to humans (ie, they just look like blurry dark blobs). Sure, there are differences among organisms in their sensitivity to different wavelengths of light, but humans actually have a peak sensitivity around that of the fluorescence of scorpions (in the green wavelengths, around 555nm).
I find the idea that fluorescence itself (ie. the absorption of uv light and the emission of its energy as light in the visible spectrum) has an adaptive value to be unbelievably unlikely, PARTICULARLY among nocturnal organisms. Even when the moon is full and the sky is clear and unobstructed, moonlight is already MUCH weaker than sunlight, and the difference in the UV spectrum is even larger. The amount of UV light that the moon reflects is TINY, so the idea that organisms have specifically evolved mechanisms to turn that minuscule amount of UV light into an even more minuscule amount of visible light (amounts which are not visible) just seems utterly insane to me. I think that to answer the animal fluorescence question, it would be much more useful to figure out which chemicals are involved, what other functions they may have, and whether changing the specific chemical bonds involved in the fluorescence would have any effect on those functions.

IF the fluorescent mechanism has any adaptive value, it is probably in the opposite way people usually talk about it- it would be in making the fluorescent areas LESS visible, in the UV spectrum. The absorption of UV light means that those UV rays aren't being reflected, so the fluorescent areas are a bit darker in the UV spectrum. That could in theory be a way for organisms to hide or something, but the emission into visible light would be incidental. I think that kind of adaptation would also be much more useful in diurnal organisms.

- By Nissim Ezekiel

I remember the night my mother
was stung by a scorpion. Ten hours
of steady rain had driven him
to crawl beneath a sack of rice.

Parting with his poison - flash
of diabolic tail in the dark room -
he risked the rain again.

The peasants came like swarms of flies
and buzzed the name of God a hundred times
to paralyse the Evil One.

With candles and with lanterns
throwing giant scorpion shadows
on the mud-baked walls
they searched for him: he was not found.
They clicked their tongues.
With every movement that the scorpion made his poison moved in Mother's blood, they said.

May he sit still, they said
May the sins of your previous birth
be burned away tonight, they said.
May your suffering decrease
the misfortunes of your next birth, they said.
May the sum of all evil
balanced in this unreal world

against the sum of good
become diminished by your pain.
May the poison purify your flesh

of desire, and your spirit of ambition,
they said, and they sat around
on the floor with my mother in the centre,
the peace of understanding on each face.
More candles, more lanterns, more neighbours,
more insects, and the endless rain.
My mother twisted through and through,
groaning on a mat.
My father, sceptic, rationalist,
trying every curse and blessing,
powder, mixture, herb and hybrid.
He even poured a little paraffin
upon the bitten toe and put a match to it.
I watched the flame feeding on my mother.
I watched the holy man perform his rites to tame the poison with an incantation.
After twenty hours
it lost its sting.

My mother only said
Thank God the scorpion picked on me
And spared my children.

One of the reasons positive tests like this guy uses for the UV-detection hypothesis are NOT scientific is that they don't eliminate alternative causes for the results.
For example, for all he knows bleaching the scorpion by exposing it to UV until it stops fluorescing also has some other effect, like changing its behavior or blinding it to UV. So that test does not "conclude" that the fluorescence is acting as a UV detector, but instead IMPLIES that it MIGHT be so.
This is why hard science always uses falsification tests, not positive tests. Positivism is not scientific.

They are layers of membranes- like pages of a book- in the exoskeleton of scorpions these membranes trap and hold their oxygen. Florescence is an interesting thing found across the many groups of arachnids. Interestingly it seems even within orders or even families it can vary a lot. Recently I have been using UV light to find different species of harvestmen, and locally it seems members of the Suborder Laniatores often seem to floresce, but members of the Suborder Eupnoi tend not to.  But even within genera it seems to vary a lot, like some algidia (like chiltoni seem to glow with most of the body, where as viridata seems to only really glow on the legs). Some species like karamea lobata seem to glow when freshly molted, but not with a solid exoskeleton. Of course this is a limited personal observation driven data set in areas close to my home. But all in all, it seems complicated, and even in different species in the same genera different drivers may be at play.
Or, more likely, the paint did not work in blocking all of the light or it is leaking past other parts of their head onto the eye.

Hypothesis:
The chemical in scorpions which converts a UV photon into a visible photon does so by its molecule absorbing some of the photon's energy and then reëmitting it when its electrons are raised to a higher energy state, and thereby breaking a particular ionic bond, exothermically releasing heat as kinetic energy into its molecular neighborhood. The scorpion doesn't directly react to the UV light, but to the sensation of heat, essentially. This could be why the scorpion doesn't die from UV radiation, but flees it, but doesn't recognize it after repeated exposure, once that particular, unused compound is exhausted

Most scorpions glow a bluish-green color when illuminated by UV light or natural moonlight. They are able to shine thanks to their thin and transparent external film that covers their exoskeleton called the cuticle. This fluorescence is due to the existence of two chemical compounds in the cuticle: β-carboline and 7-hydroxy-4-methylcoumarin.
